Thank you guys,

I like your truism of 'look at everything'. How else are y=
ou going 
to learn. Of course, you must look at bad and good. Then you 
und=
erstand the difference. 

I should not have brought up the temper - it's a =
lousy job of a fake 
temper. Whoever applied the fake temper should be shot=
! I refuse to 
leave it alone, I must have it removed. You can see the scra=
tches 
left by what-ever tool the idiot used. Yes. it's only on the side 
o=
pposite the (?)mei. 

Thanks, let me know about the other character.

Ellio=
tt

te:

> Tom,
> 
> It's a pretty lousy MUNE-  I have another character in mi=
nd but 
haven't looked for it yet.  It is well-known that most signatures o=
n 
kogatana are spurious, and IMHO these are no exception.  Elliot, I 
am s=
orry but it pains me to say that the characters are crudely 
chiselled with=
 no finesse whatsoever.  A cursory run through my 
kogatana book does not r=
eveal any examples signed in such a 
rudimentary manner.  I have found a Ta=
dahiro but it is nothing like 
the piece under consideration.  I doubt ther=
e is much to learn from 
these pieces.  It always pays to bear in mind one =
of Albert 
Yamanaka's immortal sayings "Looking at bad swords ruins your ey=
e".  
It is no less true for kogatana...  But as Tom says, thanks for 
post=
ing Elliot.  As a counter to Albert's advice, one of my truisms 
has always=
 been "Look at everything"...
> 
> Regards,
> Barry Thomas.
